remarks: Define conjunction (logical 'and').  Definition of [Margaris] p. 49.  When both the left and right operand are true, the result is true; when either is false, the result is false.  For example, it is true that ` ( 2 = 2 /\ 3 = 3 ) ` .  After we define the constant true ` T. ` ( ~ df-tru ) and the constant false ` F. ` ( ~ df-fal ), we will be able to prove these truth table values: ` ( ( T. /\ T. ) <-> T. ) ` ( ~ truantru ), ` ( ( T. /\ F. ) <-> F. ) ` ( ~ truanfal ), ` ( ( F. /\ T. ) <-> F. ) ` ( ~ falantru ), and ` ( ( F. /\ F. ) <-> F. ) ` ( ~ falanfal ). Contrast with ` \/ ` ( ~ df-or ), ` -> ` ( ~ wi ), ` -/\ ` ( ~ df-nan ), and ` \/_ ` ( ~ df-xor ) .  (Contributed by NM, 5-Jan-1993.)
